Dear Student_E,

Thank you for checking in again, and I appreciate your continued clarity that School_C is your first choice.

At this point (round 10), we still cannot confirm that our higher-priority candidates are no longer in play. In particular, there are candidates ahead of you in our priority order who may still turn to School_C if their higher-ranked options do not work out in the next rounds. Because we have only one seat, we need to keep it available until it becomes clearer that those candidates will not be pursuing us.

That said, I want to be transparent: we do recognize your consistent commitment, and if the market progresses and it becomes clear that the higher-priority candidates are no longer available to us, we will be able to revisit you quickly.

If you’d like, you can also tell us whether you currently have any pending offers or active conversations with other schools—this helps us understand your timeline while we continue to monitor the market.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

The specific condition under which we would be able to move forward with an offer to you is: if it becomes clear that the higher-priority candidates are no longer available to us (e.g., they match elsewhere) or we reach a later stage with no indications of interest from them and we need to finalize our seat.

School_C remains my first choice, and if you extend an offer at any point, I will accept immediately and withdraw from all other options.

Could you let me know what would count, from your side, as “clear that higher-priority candidates are no longer available” at this stage (e.g., do you need to actually hear that they matched elsewhere, or is there a round/time threshold after which you finalize the seat)? If it helps you finalize responsibly, I’m also willing to give a firm commitment that if you offer me the seat this round, I will accept right away.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_C remains unmatched and it is my top true preference. I have been repeatedly rejected because they are holding the seat for higher-priority students. At round 12, the best move is to continue engagement without forcing another likely rejection, while providing the timeline information they requested and asking what concrete trigger would convert to an offer. I will signal I am still unmatched, can accept immediately, and can give them a short exclusivity window to reduce their risk.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for the clear update on your timeline, and for reiterating your willingness to commit immediately.

On what would count as “clear” at this stage: because we do not receive a perfect real-time confirmation that other candidates have matched, we have to use a practical combination of (a) whether any higher-priority candidates actually contact/apply to School_C, and (b) a time/round threshold after which we finalize rather than risk leaving the seat unfilled.

Concretely, if we do not receive an [APPLY] from any higher-priority candidate (Student_B, Student_A, or Student_D) by the end of the next round, we will be prepared to finalize our remaining seat with the best available committed candidate at that point.

If you would like to be considered for immediate finalization as soon as we are able, please send an [APPLY] to School_C (you can do so this round). That will let us move quickly the moment the seat is released.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[TALK]
conversation.thought: School_C’s true priority ranks Student_E 4th (behind Student_B, Student_A, Student_D). However, by round 12 School_C is the only unmatched school remaining, and Student_E reports no other active talks/offers, implying other students likely matched elsewhere and are unlikely to apply now. With quota 1 and no inbound interest from higher-priority students, continuing to hold the seat risks ending unmatched. Student_E is still on the acceptable list, so keep dialogue open and set a concrete finalization threshold while inviting an APPLY to close immediately if no higher-priority applicant appears.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for submitting your [APPLY] and for your clear, consistent commitment to School_C.

At this moment, we are still holding our single remaining seat for the possibility that a higher-priority candidate (Student_B, Student_A, or Student_D) may apply as a fallback. Because of that, we are not able to extend an offer to you this round.

However, consistent with what we shared earlier: if we do not receive an [APPLY] from any of those higher-priority candidates by the end of the next round, we will be prepared to finalize our remaining seat with the best available committed candidate at that point. If you re-submit an [APPLY] next round, we will be able to move immediately if the seat is released.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions

[REJECT]
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority is B > A > D > E > C. Student_E is 4th, but they are the only student currently applying to us and have repeatedly committed to accept immediately. Given the history, we set a practical threshold: if no higher-priority candidate (B/A/D) applies by the end of the next round, we would finalize with the best available committed candidate. In round 13 we still have not received any [APPLY] from B/A/D, but to remain consistent with our stated threshold and to avoid prematurely giving up a chance at a higher-priority student, we should wait one more round. Therefore, reject this round while explicitly stating we will accept next round if no higher-priority applicant applies, and invite them to re-apply immediately next round so we can finalize quickly.
